The mechanism, regioselectivity and chemoseletivity in the metal-catalyst-controlled selective functionalization of carbazole with diazo-naphthalen-2(1H)-one have been explored by the density functional theory (DFT) in the model systems composed of the (IPr)AuCl/AgSbF6, Pd(OAc)2, and Rh2(OAc)4 catalysts. The DFT calculations reveal that the key intermediate in the (IPr)AuCl/AgSbF6 system has the strongest electrophilic center compared to those in Pd- or Rh-catalyzed reactions with carbazole, resulting in the C3-alkylation product (series A). For the series B and C (Pd(OAc)2 and Rh2(OAc)4 catalytic systems), the calculation results disclose that the key intermediates are much less electrophilic than in the series A, which explains the generation of the final N-H arylation product instead of the C3-alkylation product when using these catalytic systems. Another key finding of this study is that the distortion energy and not the interaction energy plays an important role in the series A toward controlling the chemoselectivity. However, the chemoselectivity is entirely determined by the interaction energy in the series B. The interaction and distortion energies are jointly responsible for the chemoselectivity in the series C. The obtained herein results can offer very valuable information toward future design of effective and regioselective catalysts and synthetic protocols for this type of challenging reactions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords DFT Metal-Catalyzed reactions Carbazole Chemoseletivity Reaction mechanism Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Various diazo derivatives belong to an important class of substrates in organic synthesis [1] toward the generation of value-added molecules [2–4]. In particular, metal carbene complexes formed in the course of diazo decomposition are the key intermediates in the transition-metal-catalyzed conversion of diazo substrates [5]. Metal carbene species can participate in a vast variety of important reactions, including the X−H (X = C, O, N, or S) functionalization [6], cyclopropanation [7], cycloaddition [8], and tandem cross-coupling [9]. Among different transformations, the coupling of carbazoles with diazo compounds via carbene transfer represents one of the most efficient approaches to functionalize carbazole derivatives [10]. Generally, an activation of vinyl diazoacetate could generate a metal vinylcarbene species, which possesses at least 4 typical reaction modes with carbazole (Scheme 1 ). This turns very challenging the selective synthesis of target products from carbazoles. Recently, a remarkable catalyst-controlled selective functionalization of carbazole with diazo-naphthalen-2(1H)-one has been developed by Koenigs and co-workers [11]. According to experimental results, the reaction exclusively leads to the C3-alkylation products in the Au-based catalytic system, while the use of catalysis by Pd(II) or Rh(II) permits a selective N–H arylation (Scheme 2 ) [11]. The catalyst-driven control of the reaction pathways to generate different target products has been one of the most puzzling fields of organic chemistry [12]. There is an urgent demand for profound understanding of the mechanistic and regioselectivity features in this type of emergent organic transformations. In this regard, computational methods not only unveil the most reasonable mechanisms but also enable to predict some physicochemical parameters relevant to selectivity control [13]. The main goal of the present study relies in better understanding of the origin of mechanism and unique regioselectivity in these intriguing transformations involving carbazole and diazo-naphthalen-2(1H)-one (Scheme 2) [11]. To address this goal, we have performed a thorough DFT calculation study [14] to rationalize a unique selectivity observed in this reaction while using different catalytic systems. Hence, the present work (1) explores the diverse roles of the (IPr)AuCl/AgSbF6, Pd(OAc)2, and Rh2(OAc)4 catalysts, (2) provides a full theoretical rationalization of the reaction pathways, and (3) explains the mechanistic, chemo- and regioselectivity features in these metal-catalyzed reactions between carbazole and diazo-naphthalen-2(1H)-one. This study thus complements recent experimental data [11] and provides an additional insight on the mechanism and selectivity, along with a valuable information on the selection of reaction parameters in this type of significant organic reactions. 2 Computational details All calculations were carried out with the Gaussian 09 programs [14]. The geometries of all the species were fully optimized by using density functional theory (DFT) [15] and the B3LYP method [16] with the 6-31G (d, p) basis set for all atoms except for Au, Pd and Rh. The LANL2DZ [17] basis set was used for Au, Pd, and Rh. Vibrational frequency calculations carried out at the B3LYP/6-31G (d, p) level of theory were used to characterize all of the stationary points as either minima (the number of imaginary frequencies (NIMAG=0) or transition states (NIMAG=1)). The relative energies were corrected for the vibrational zero-point energies (ZPE, not scaled). The convergence criteria were used as default and the vibrational analysis was also carried out at standard conditions (1 atm., 298.15 K). The solvent effect was taken into account by single-point calculations with integral equation formalism polarizable continuum model (IEFPCM) [18] in DCM at the B3LYP-D3(BJ) [19]/6-311++G (d, p) (for Au, Pd, and Rh, LANL2TZ(f) [20], (BSII) was used). The radii and nonelectrostatic terms were taken from Truhlar and co-workers’ universal solvation model (SMD) [21]. It should be noted that the use of B3LYP to optimize the structure and B3LYP-D3(BJ) for energy calculation is widely applied in the calculations involving transition metal catalysts [22]. Furthermore, a detailed comparison of the calculation results for three catalytic systems by different functionals were displayed in Tables S1 and S2 (ESI). Unless stated otherwise, all the relative free energies discussed in the main text are calculated in solution (ΔGsol), which were obtained by B3LYP-D3(BJ)/SMD/6-311++G (d, p) //B3LYP/6-31G (d, p) (Lanl2dz). Analysis of noncovalent interactions (NCI) was performed with the Multiwfn program [23]. The 3D molecular structures were generated using the CYL-view [24]. The global electrophilicity index, ω [25] is given by the following simple expression ω = (μ2/2η), in terms of the electronic chemical potential μ and the chemical hardness η [26]. Both parameters may be approached in terms of the one electron energies of the frontier molecular orbital HOMO and LUMO, ɛH and ɛL, as μ ≈ (ɛH+ɛL)/2 and η ≈ (ɛL-ɛH), respectively [27]. Recently, Domingo et al. introduced an empirical (relative) nucleophilicity index, N [28], based on the HOMO energies obtained within the Kohn–Sham scheme, and defined as N =ɛHOMO(Nu) - ɛHOMO(TCE). The nucleophilicity N refers to tetracyanoethylene (TCE) because it presents the lowest HOMO energy in a large series of molecules already investigated in the context of polar reactions. Local electrophilicity and nucleophilicity indices, ωk and Nk , were evaluated using the following expressions: ωk = ω P k + and Nk = N P k − where P k + and P k − are the electrophilic and nucleophilic Parr functions, respectively; these were obtained through the analysis of the Mulliken atomic spin density of the radical anion and the radical cation of the studied molecules [29]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Au-catalyzed reaction of carbazole with diazo-naphthalen-2(1H)-one (series A) The computational free energy profiles for the series A (catalytic system based on (IPr)AuCl/AgSbF6) are displayed in Fig. 1 . All structural parameters and energies are given in ESI. In the series A, the first step involves the coordination of a vinyl diazo reactant Re1 to Au center, generating a gold complex A-1; this step is exergonic by -9.6 kcal/mol. Subsequent denitrogenation of A-1 occurs via a transition state A-TS1 by cleavage of the C−N bond with a free energy barrier of 11.0 kcal/mol to give a gold-carbene complex A-2, with a free energy release of -25.5 kcal/mol. Next, the adduct complex between A-2 and Re2 has been located in our calculation. This step is exergonic by -0.6 kcal/mol. After the formation of A-22, there are at least four possible reaction pathways based on chemo- and regioselectivity. For pathways a, the N–H arylation between the carbene C and N sites would give, via A-TSa1, the corresponding intermediate A-1a. In A-TSa1, the bond distance for C4-N is 1.956 Å and the carbazole and diazo-naphthalen-2(1H)-one are on the same side. The free energy of activation for this step is 5.7 kcal/mol (Fig. 1), while the free reaction energy for A-1a is -12.3 kcal/mol relatively to A-2. Alternatively, the C−H alkylation between the carbene C and the C1, C2 or C3 sites of carbazole would lead to the pathways b, c, and d. The free energies of activation for A-TSb1, A-TSc1, and A-TSd1 are 3.8, 8.1, and 6.3 kcal/mol, respectively. The calculation results point out that the alkylation steps between the N and C1, C2, C3 sites of carbazole are highly regioselective. Although this step does not determine the reaction rate and considering that the electrophilic attack is an irreversible step, a lower activation free energy found for A-TSb1 suggests that the reaction at the C3 position (pathway b) is the most preferred. In A-TSb1, the bond distance for C4-C [3] is 2.199 Å and the carbazole and diazo-naphthalen-2(1H)-one are also on the same side. This outcome of DFT results well agrees with the experimental data [11]. Subsequently, there is a shift of proton from N (via A-TSa2) or C (via A-TSb2) to carbonyl oxygen of diazo-naphthalen-2(1H)-one to form the final products P1 or P2 and regenerate the gold catalyst. These steps are exergonic by -17.4 and -17.0 kcal/mol, and the free energy barriers are 0.1 and 4.0 kcal/mol, respectively. Furthermore, low free energy barriers found for a proton transfer step indicate that this is a very easy process, which is consistent with the experimental results revealing no effect of water on chemoselectivity. 3.2 Pd or Rh-catalyzed reaction of carbazole with diazo-naphthalen-2(1H)-one (series B or C) The computational free energy profiles for the series B and C (catalytic systems based on Pd(OAc)2 and Rh2(OAc)4) are displayed in Figs. 2 and 3 . In the series B (Pd(OAc)2 catalyst), the coordination of vinyl diazo reactant Re1 to Pd leads to a complex B-1 and this step is endergonic by 4.2 kcal/mol. Subsequent denitrogenation of B-1 occurs via a transition state B-TS1 by cleaving the C−N bond (with a free energy barrier of 13.5 kcal/mol) to form a Pd carbene complex B-2 with a free energy release of -12.8 kcal/mol. Next, the formation of the adduct complex B-22 is exergonic by -1.5 kcal/mol. Indeed, similar pathways (a, b, c, and d) were calculated in the present study. Starting from B-22, four possible reaction pathways based on chemo- and regioselectivity were located. The free energies of activation for these steps are 2.2, 7.2, 12.6, and 11.5 kcal/mol for B-TSa1, B-TSb1, B-TSc1, and B-TSd1, respectively (Fig. 2). In B-TSa1, the carbazole and diazo-naphthalen-2(1H)-one are on the same side. However, the carbazole and diazo-naphthalen-2(1H)-one are on the opposite side for B-TSb1. Unlike in the series A, the calculation results in the series B show that the N–H arylation reaction is facilitated. The next step includes a shift of proton from N (via B-TSa2) or C (via B-TSb2) to carbonyl oxygen of diazo-naphthalen-2(1H)-one to furnish the final products P1 or P2 and regenerate the palladium catalyst. These steps are exergonic by -17.0 and -28.1 kcal/mol, and the free energy barriers are 1.8 and 3.5 kcal/mol, respectively. To verify the effect of another metal-based catalyst, the reaction pathway for Rh2(OAc)4 (series C) was calculated (Fig. 3). Similar to the series B, the calculation results suggest that the pathway for the formation of the N–H arylation product is also more favorable in the series C. Again, the outcome of the DFT calculations well agrees with the experimental results [11]. 3.3 Origin of chemoselectivity and regioselectivity After elucidating the detailed reaction mechanism, we turned our attention to an important point of chemo- and regioselectivity control by the catalyst. It is well known that the nature of the gold(I)-C bond has been a longstanding discussion in the field of gold-catalysis [30]. To further analyze the nature of A-2, B-2, and C-2, the natural population analysis (NPA) charge distribution and the Wiberg bond indices were calculated for the C4−C5 and M−C4 bonds (Fig. 4 ). For A-2, the NPA charges of Au and C1 centers are 0.362 and -0.154 au, respectively. The Wiberg bond indices for the Au−C4 and C4−C5bonds are 0.656 and 1.363, respectively. However, the calculated NPA charges for Pd and C4 centers in B-2 are 0.625 and 0.06 au, respectively. And the NPA charges calculated for the Rh and C4 centers in C-2 are 0.491 and 0.073 au, respectively. The Wiberg bond index of the Rh−C4 and C4−C5bonds is 0.857 and 1.275, respectively. Considering the natural population analysis (NPA) charge distribution and the Wiberg bond indices, the three catalysts differ in charge distribution and bond order. However, we cannot yet establish the origin of the chemoselectivity. Subsequently, a global reactivity index (GRI) analysis was carried out to identify a role of the reactant's nucleophilicity [31]. As shown in Table 1 , the following values for electrophilicity (ω = 0.98, 21.4, 8.51, 7.28 eV) and the nucleophilicity (N = 4.03, 0.76, 3.23, 3.91 eV) were obtained for Re2, A-2, B-2, and C-2, respectively. These values indicate that all Re2 have a very low eletrophilicity ω parameter and a substantially higher nucleophilicity N, thus acting as strong nucleophiles. In contrast, A-2, B-2, and C-2 have a higher electrophilicity ω parameter and thus act as electrophiles. Furthermore, the local nucleophilicity (Nk ) values for the X atoms of Re2 (X = N, C1, C2 and C3) are 1.27, 0.79, -0.39, and 0.87 eV, respectively. These values suggest that the N and C3 atoms have a superior local nucleophilicity (Nk ) than that of the C1 and C2 atoms, which makes N and C3 to be more prone to nucleophilic attacks to form intermediates. For A-2, B-2, and C-2, the local nucleophilicity (Nk ) values for the carbene C atoms are 10.92, 3.97 and 3.55 eV, respectively. These results reveal that the electrophilicity for carbene C of A-2 is much greater than that of B-2 and C-2, which provides the possibility to invert the chemoselectivity. Finally, the distortion/interaction analysis was carried out (Figure 5 ) [32]. The distortion energies for A-TSa1, A-TSb1, A-TSc1, and A-TSd1 are 17.9, 17.0, 18.6, and 18.0 kcal/mol, respectively. Hence, the distortion energies play a more important role in controlling the selectivity of reactions if compared with the interaction energies. For the series B and C, the distortion energies for B-TSa1, B-TSb1, B-TSc1, B-TSd1 and C-TSa1, C-TSb1, C-TSc1, C-TSd1 are 18.4, 15.2, 18.5, 23.8 and 10.4, 12.6, 16.1, 26.3 kcal/mol, respectively. In addition, the calculated interaction energies for B-TSa1, B-TSb1, B-TSc1, B-TSd1 and C-TSa1, C-TSb1, C-TSc1, C-TSd1 are -25.1, -14.6, -13.1, -22.0 and -14.5, -10.7, -8.2, -23.3 kcal/mol, respectively. These data indicate that for the series B the chemoselectivity is entirely determined by the interaction energies. In the series C, the interaction and distortion energies are jointly responsible for the chemoselectivity. However, the regioselectivity at the C1, C2, and C3 sites is dependent on the distortion energies whether for series B or C. To illuminate the effect of interaction energy, the noncovalent interaction analysis was also performed for B-TSa1 and B-TSb1 (Fig. 6 ) [33,34]. The biggest difference between the non-covalent interactions that determine the different chemoselective transition states concerns B-TSa1 that has the strong CO-π (CO and carbazole) and π-π (carbazole and diazo-naphthalen-2(1H)-one) interactions, whereas B-TSb1 reveals only the CO-π interactions (CO and carbazole). This difference in noncovalent interactions is likely responsible for the observed chemoselectivity [35]. 4 Conclusions In summary, the mechanism, chemo- and regioselectivity in the metal-catalyst-controlled selective functionalization of carbazole with diazo-naphthalen-2(1H)-one were investigated and fully rationalized by DFT calculations. In the series A ((IPr)AuCl/AgSbF6 catalytic system), the key intermediate has the strongest electrophilic center compared to the Pd(OAc)2 and Rh2(OAc)4 catalysts in the reactions with carbazole, resulting in the C3-alkylation product P1 instead of the N–H arylation product P2. For the series B and C (Pd (OAc)2 and Rh2(OAc)4 catalytic systems), the calculation results disclose that the key intermediates are significantly less electrophilic than in the series A, what explains the generation of the final N-H arylation product instead of the C3-alkylation product when using these catalytic systems. Further key findings of this study are that the distortion energy and not the interaction energy plays a crucial role in the series A toward controlling the chemoselectivity. However, the chemoselectivity is entirely determined by the interaction energy in the series B. The interaction and distortion energies are jointly responsible for the chemoselectivity in the series C. We believe that the obtained herein results will offer important information toward the design of effective and regioselective catalysts and synthetic protocols for this type of compelling organic transformations . coredata.dc:description: The mechanism, regioselectivity and chemoseletivity in the metal-catalyst-controlled selective functionalization of carbazole with diazo-naphthalen-2(1H)-one have been explored by the density functional theory (DFT) in the model systems composed of the (IPr)AuCl/AgSbF6, Pd(OAc)2, and Rh2(OAc)4 catalysts. The DFT calculations reveal that the key intermediate in the (IPr)AuCl/AgSbF6 system has the strongest electrophilic center compared to those in Pd- or Rh-catalyzed reactions with carbazole, resulting in the C3-alkylation product (series A). For the series B and C (Pd(OAc)2 and Rh2(OAc)4 catalytic systems), the calculation results disclose that the key intermediates are much less electrophilic than in the series A, which explains the generation of the final N-H arylation product instead of the C3-alkylation product when using these catalytic systems. Another key finding of this study is that the distortion energy and not the interaction energy plays an important role in the series A toward controlling the chemoselectivity. However, the chemoselectivity is entirely determined by the interaction energy in the series B. The interaction and distortion energies are jointly responsible for the chemoselectivity in the series C. The obtained herein results can offer very valuable information toward future design of effective and regioselective catalysts and synthetic protocols for this type of challenging reactions.
coredata.dc:title: DFT rationalization of metal-catalyst-controlled coupling of carbazole with diazo-naphthalen-2(1H)-one
